data.title: Sports in German: 121 Solid Words to Knock it out of the Park
data.meta_description: From football to golf, to even quidditch, sports are a fun way to connect with people from all around the world, including German speakers.
data.text:
Sports are a fun way to connect to people from all around the world.

When youâre moving your body while playing soccer or going for a jog with a German-speaking friend, language learning automatically feels easy and natural.

For a new German-learner, thereâs nothing like striking up a soccer match to make German friends! Or starting a conversation about any other sport - this can be basketball, equestrian vaulting or a boxing match.

Especially if you find yourself in a German-speaking country, some of the best ways to practice your German are sports-related:

Ask a Germanâspeaker about their favorite sports to get to know them better

Experience a huge part of the German culture by going to a soccer match in the stadium and singing along to some FuÃball chants

Watch sports on German tv and listen closely to the commentator

Take up a team sport and blend in with your German-speaking team mates

How do you say âsportsâ in German

âSportsâ in German is âSportâ. While itâs a plural word in English, itâs a singular-only word in German. If youâre referring to different kinds of sports, you say âSportartenâ.

Thereâs an abundance of these - from golf and tennis to swimming and horse-back riding. So weâll teach you about the most popular ones and how to say them in German.

How to talk about sports in German

Striking up a conversation about sports can be as simple as asking someone what sports they play or like to watch on tv. Start with these basics.

Machst du Sport?

English: Do you workout?

Was ist dein Lieblingssport?

English: Whatâs your favorite sport?

Magst du Mannschaftssportarten?

English: Do you like team sports?

Try to find common ground through shared interests. You can bond over your love for a specific sport, a famous team or even over a mutual aversion for sports altogether!

Ich interessiere mich fÃ¼r Tennis.

English: Iâm into tennis.

Ich bin ein Fan von Borussia Dortmund.

English: Iâm a fan of Borussia Dortmund.

Ich mag keinen Sport!

English: I donât like sports!

Sport-related verbs

Sports are all about movement and being active, so verbs are especially important when you want to talk about them.

English German IPATo playSpielen[ËÊpiËlÉn]To do sportsSport machen; Sport treiben[ÊpÉÊt Ëmaxn; ÊpÉÊt ËtÊaÉªÌ¯bnÌ©]To practiceÃben[ËyËbn]To workoutTrainieren[tÊÉËniËÊÉn]To train for the OlympicsFÃ¼r Olympia trainieren[fyËÉÌ¯ oËlÊmpiÌ¯a tÊÉËniËÊÉn]To scorePunkten[ËpÊÅktnÌ©]To winGewinnen[É¡ÉËvÉªnÉn]To beatSchlagen[ËÊlaËÉ¡nÌ©]To tieRemis spielen[ÊÉËmiË ËÊpiËlÉn]To cheatBetrÃ¼gen[bÉËtÊyËÉ¡nÌ©]To loseVerlieren[fÉÉÌ¯ËliËÊÉn]To drawUnentschieden spielen[ËÊnÊÉntËÊiËdnÌ© ËÊpiËlÉn]To dribbleDribbeln[ËdÊÉªblÌ©n]To bouncePrellen[ËpÊÉlÉn]To take partTeilnehmen[ËtaÉªÌ¯lËneËmÉn]

List of sports in German

The good thing when youâre learning about sports in German is that the German words are often the same or at least very similar.

American Football in German is âFootballâ, basketball in German is âBasketballâ and volleyball in German is âVolleyballâ. Easy enough, right?

Outdoor sportsÂ

When it comes to outdoor sports, which we call âOutdoor Sportâ or more formally âFreiluftsportâ, Germany is all about soccer!

Of course we call it âFuÃballâ since you hit the Ball with your FuÃ and thatâs just how logical the German language is.

English German IPASoccerFuÃball[ËfuËsËbal]American footballFootball[ËfÊtbÉËl]Outdoor basketballBasketball[ËbaËskÉtËbal]BaseballBaseball[ËbÉÉªÌ¯sbÉËl]GolfGolf[É¡Élf]Road cyclingStraÃenradfahren[ËÊtÊaËsnÌ©ËÊaËtËfaËÊÉn]TennisTennis[ËtÉnÉªs]HikingWandern[ËvandÉn]Mountain bikingMountainbikefahren[ËmaÊÌ¯ntÉªnËbaÉªÌ¯kËfaËÊÉn]Rock climbingFelsenklettern[ËfÉlznÌ©ËklÉtÉn]BadmintonBadminton; Federball[ËbÉtmÉªntnÌ©; ËfeËdÉËbal]ArcheryBogenschieÃen[ËboËÉ¡nÌ©ËÊiËsnÌ©]ParkourParkour[paÊËkuËÉÌ¯]BMXingBMXen[beÉmiksn]SkateboardingSkateboarden[ËskÉÉªÌ¯tboËÉÌ¯tn]SnowboardingSnowboarden[ËsnoËËboËÉÌ¯dnÌ©]SkiingSki[ÊiË]FrisbeeFrisbee[ËfÊÉªsbi]Horse ridingReiten[ËÊaÉªÌ¯tnÌ©]PoloPolo[ËpoËlo]DressageDressurreiten[dÊÉËsuËÉÌ¯ËÊaÉªÌ¯tnÌ©]RugbyRugby[ËÊakbi]CricketCricket[ËkÊÉªkÉt]Beach volleyballBeachvolleyball[ËbiËtÊtËvÉlibal]ParaglidingParagleiten[ËpaÊaËÉ¡laÉªÌ¯tn]Track and FieldLeichtathletik[ËlaÉªÌ¯Ã§tÊatËleËtik]RunningLaufen[ËlaÊÌ¯fnÌ©]SprintSprint[ÊpÊÉªnt]JoggingJoggen[ËdÊÉÉ¡n]MarathonMarathon[ËmaËÊatÉn]High jumpHochsprung[ËhoËxËÊpÊÊÅ]Long jumpWeitsprung[ËvaÉªÌ¯tÊpÊÊÅ]Discus throwDiskuswurf[ËdÉªskÊsËvÊÊf]Hammer throwHammerwerfen[ËhamÉËvÉÊfnÌ©]Javelin throwSpeerwurf[ËÊpeËÉÌ¯ËvÊÊf]

Water sportsÂ

âWater sportsâ in German are âWassersportartenâ (vah-sa-shport-art-en). Some of the most popular ones are swimming, surfing, kiteboating and kayaking - and if you enjoy scuba diving, you should definitely try it in one of the crystal clear Alpine lakes in Germany, Austria or Switzerland!

English German IPASwimmingSchwimmen[ËÊvÉªmÉn]FreestyleFreestyle[fÊistajl]BackstrokeRÃ¼ckenschwimmen[ËÊÊknÌ©ËÊvÉªmÉ]ButterflySchmetterling[ËÊmÉtÉlÉªÅ]BreaststrokeBrustschwimmen[ËbÊÊstËÊvÉªmÉn]DivingTauchen[ËtaÊÌ¯xnÌ©]Water poloWasserball[ËvasÉËbal]Synchronized swimmingSynchronschwimmen[zÊnËkÊoËnËÊvÉªmÉn]BodyboardingBodyboarding[ËbÉdÉªbÉÊdËiÅÉ¡]SurfingSurfen[ËsÅËÉÌ¯fnÌ©]WindsurfingWindsurfen[ËvÉªntËsÅËÉÌ¯fÉn]WakeboardingWakeboarden[ËvÉÉªÌ¯kËbÉËÉÌ¯tnÌ©]WaterskiingWasserskilaufen[ËvasÉÊiËËËlaÊÌ¯fnÌ©]KayakingKajaken[ËkaËjakn]CanyoningCanyoning[kanjÉniÅ]SnorkelingSchnorcheln[ËÊnÉÊÃ§lÌ©n]SailingSegeln[ËzeËÉ¡lÌ©n]RowingRudern[ËÊuËdÉn]PaddleboardingPaddeln[Ëpadln]RaftingRafting[ËÊaËftÉªÅ]

Indoor sportsÂ

Many indoor sports (Hallensport) are the same in German as they are in English. So people will understand you perfectly, whether you mention âyogaâ, âpilatesâ, âboxingâ or any kind of dance - from foxtrot to hip hop.

English GermanIPAIndoor soccerHallenfuÃball[ËhalÉnËfuËsbal]Ice skatingSchlittschuhlaufen[ËÊlÉªtËÊuËËlaÊÌ¯fnÌ©]SquashSquash[skvÉÊ]PilatesPilates[pi:ËlatÉs ]YogaYoga[ËjoËÉ¡a]VolleyballVolleyball[ËvÉlÉÉªÌ¯Ëbal]BasketballBasketball[ËbaËskÉtËbal]SoftballSoftball[sÉftbol]Table tennisTischtennis[ËtÉªÊËtÉnÉªs]Indoor cyclingIndoor-Radfahren[Éªndo:ÉÌ¯ ËÊaËtËfaËÊÉn]WrestlingWrestling[ËÊÉslÉªÅ]GymnasticsGymnastik; Turnen[ËÉ¡ÊmËnastÉªk; ËtÊÊnÉn]KarateKarate[kaËÊaËtÉ]JudoJudo[ËjuËdo]FencingFechten[ËfÉÃ§tnÌ©]BoxingBoxen[ËbÉksnÌ©]KickboxingKickboxen[ËkÉªkËbÉksnÌ©]CapoeiraCapoeira[kapoËeËÊa]DanceTanz[tants]

Other games in German

Not all sports need a lot of action! Thereâs a German word referring to mental exercises called âDenksportâ (Think-sports). This includes activities like chess, card games and board games.

English GermanIPACard gamesKartenspiele[ËkaÊtnÌ©ËÊpiËlÉ]Board gamesBrettspiele[ËbÊÉtËÊpiËlÉ]Video gamesVideospiele[ËviËdeoËÊpiËlÉ]Drinking gamesTrinkspiele[ËtÊÉªÅkËÊpiËlÉ]ChessSchach[Êax]CheckersDame[ËdaËmÉ]PokerPoker[ËpoËkÉ]DominoDomino[ËdoËmino]DartsDart[daËÉÌ¯t]PoolBillard[ËbÉªljaÊt]JengaJenga[jÉÅgaÉÌ¯]MonopolyMonopoly[mo:Ëno:po:lÉª]Role playingRollenspiel[ËÊÉlÉnËÊpiËl]QuidditchQuidditch[kvÉªtdi:ttÍ¡Ê]

Sports-related vocab in German

Hereâs a list of everything we missed so far - from the athletes to their sports equipment.

English GermanIPAAthleteAthlet[atËleËt]TeamTeam[tiËm]CoachCoach[kÉÊÌ¯tÍ¡Ê]FieldFeld[fÉlt]RinkSpielflÃ¤che[ËÊpiËlËflÉÃ§É]PoolPool; Schwimmbecken[puËl; ËÊvÉªmËbÉknÌ©]CourtPlatz[plats]DoublesDoppel[ËdÉplÌ©]Sports venueSportstÃ¤tte[ÊpÉÊtËÊtÉtÉ]Sporting fieldSportplatz[ËÊpÉÊtËplatÍ¡s]Sports equipmentSportausrÃ¼stung[ÊpÉÊtËaÊÌ¯sËÊÊstÊÅ]ArenaArena[aËÊeËna]TrackBahn[baËn]GoalkeeperTorwart[ËtoËÉÌ¯ËvaÊt]PlayerSpieler[ËÊpiËlÉ]On your markAuf die PlÃ¤tze[aÊÌ¯f diË ËplÉtÍ¡sÉ]Get setFertig[ËfÉÊtÉªÃ§]Go!Los![loËs]

Example conversations about sports in German

Asking someone what sports they do is a great way to start a conversation. Here are some examples of how this might go in German.

SpeakerGermanEnglishLeonWelche Sportarten machst du?What kinds of sports do you do?JosefineIch tanze Hip Hop und Breakdance, und du?I dance hip hop and breakdance, and you?LeonCool! Ich mache keinen Sport. Vielleicht kannst du mir ein paar Schritte zeigen?Cool. I don't do sports. Maybe you can show me a few steps?JosefineKlar, und wenn es dir SpaÃ macht, solltest du mit zum Tanzkurs kommen!Sure, and if you enjoy it, you should come to dance class with me!

In case the other person isnât doing any sports, you can always ask if they watch sports on tv.

SpeakerGermanEnglishMiaHast du das FuÃballspiel gestern gesehen?Did you watch the soccer game last night?HannesJa, ich wÃ¼nschte, Eintracht Frankfurt hÃ¤tte gewonnen!Yes, I wish Eintracht Frankfurt had won!MiaDu bist Eintracht-Fan?Youâre an Eintracht fan?HannesEigentlich nicht. Ich fand bloÃ, dass sie gestern besser gespielt haben.Usually Iâm not. I just thought they played better yesterday.

Example conversations whilst playing sports

When youâre joining a sports team or meeting others to work out together, itâs helpful to know how to make plans for that.

SpeakerGermanEnglishAmirWillst du mit mir und den anderen zum See kommen?Do you want to come to the lake with me and the others?MaxIch kann nicht schwimmen.I canât swim.AmirMacht nichts. Das bringen wir dir bei!No problem, weâll teach you.MaxEcht? Dann bin ich dabei. Ich muss aber erst mal eine Badehose kaufen.Really? Then Iâm in. I have to buy some swim trunks first though.

Once youâre in the game or working out, there isnât always that much talk. Just remember some simple phrases for the game or activity.

SpeakerGermanEnglishSaraHey, gib mir den Ball!Hey, give me the ball!LeonieHier!Here!SaraAchtung!Watch out!LeonieGut gemacht!Good job!

Most popular sports in different German-speaking countries

Itâs probably no surprise to you that in Germany, Austria and Switzerland alike, by far the most popular sport is soccer or âFuÃballâ.

In Switzerland, Austria and the South of Germany, where itâs chilly and snowy, skiing is also very popular, along with other winter sports like snowboarding and ice-skating, and ice-hockey

German-speaking countries also have some rather unusual sports including Underwater Hockey, River Surfing and of course the famous âKastenlaufâ:

This âsportâ requires different teams to race each other while carrying a crate of beer. Of course the contents of the beer crate have to be consumed before youâre allowed to cross the finish line - Yes, somehow we even found a way to make sports about drinking beer!

Sports-related idioms in German

There are some interesting sports-related idioms in German, a popular one being âam Ball bleibenâ. It means âto stay with the ballâ, which evokes a clear picture: When you stay with the ball, you stay where the action is. You stay on top of things.

GermanLiteral translationOriginMeaningAm Ball bleiben To stay with the ballSoccerTo stay on top of thingsDen Ball flach haltenTo keep the ball lowSoccerTo play it safeEin Eigentor schieÃenTo score an own goalSoccerTo shoot oneself in the footNach der Pfeife von jemandem tanzenTo dance after someoneâs whistleDanceTo do what someone saysJemanden in Schach haltenTo keep someone in checkChessTo keep someone under controlMit harten Bandagen kÃ¤mpfenTo fight with hard bandagesBoxingTo fight as hard as you canBei jemandem punkten To score with someoneCompetitive sportsTo impress someone

Stay with the ball

As an important Denksport, language learning works just like sports in many ways: Itâs always gonna be difficult when you first start out but the more time you invest in practicing, the easier it gets.

The key is to stay with the ball, meaning: show up and give it all you got.

If you want to compare it to running, keep in mind that itâs more like a marathon than a sprint. You wonât get too far in a short amount of time, but if you stick with it, it will be extremely rewarding in the long run.

More than anything else, language learning is a team sport though. Ultimately, you canât play it by yourself and youâll get the most out of it if you surround yourself with great team members to learn from.
